data.text: What is your ideal/dream bike for bikepacking?
What would be your ideal/dream bike for bikepacking?

Tumbleweed Prospector with Rohloff, because I love going off road and I just spent a ton of time researching this before buying one. https://www.longbikeride.net/2022/05/05/custom-tumbleweed-prospector-for-off-road-world-touring.html

data.author: Anthony Newman

data.text: just got me a 2022 revolt advanced 2 and I need to get all the gear and go. Any tent recommendations for a noob?
data.author: Robin Farris

data.text: Anything by Big Agnes. I love my Copper Spur HV UL1. Really lightweight and the easiest to setup.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: best of luck with your new bike. As far as tents go. I have tried a few. You need to decide on what weather you will be camping in. If you are going for 1 or 2 nights in warm weather and no rain. Go with something light and don't worry about rain flies and footprint mats. Another thing to consider is free standing or not. In other words do you need to steak down the lines to keep the tent tight and standing or can you sent this tent up on hard floors without securing it to the ground. I camp mostly in NJ, NY and PA so we are always in grass or dirt. That let me go with lighter tents. Less weight from poles. As you can tell there is more things to think about . This is where talking to locals of your area and stores like Rei come in. Rei has the best return policies. Just don't abuse it. I won't give a recommendation for any one tent because I share a few with friends. Depending on where we camp. I hope some of this information helps.
data.author: Anthony Newman

data.text: thanks! Appreciate all the info. Gives me a lot to think about
data.author: Robin Farris

data.text: definitely looking at them or Nemo Dragonly

data.text: Titanium fat bike, pinion gearbox and gates belt drive. Currently designing and building it up.
data.author: Idriss Musa

data.text: I went wihh rohloff, but curious what research lead you to pick a belt drive. What I read suggests it still has issues, such as tensioning is much harder and being noisy. Would love to hear your experience when you get the bike, as it's not hard for me to change.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: The main reasons I’m going belt drive are they far outlast a chain drive and are cheaper in the long term. Zero lubrication and degreasing. Don’t get caked up with mud. The tensioning is very easy, there is an app on your phone that tells you the correct tension by plucking it like a guitar string.
data.author: Idriss Musa

data.text: already got it. Set up currently with 29x2.25 chained, but will take 26x4 (on order) and set up SS belt drive, or rohlhoff.

data.text: I want a Surly Ogre frameset, Shimano 1x Deore/SLX/XT, Schwalbe 29x2.35 Big Apples, SKS Velo 65 Mountain 29 fenders w/ DT Swiss Hu 1900 Spline. Kinda liking the new champagne color, but it's not a great time for me to be buying a frameset right now. May have to wait for the next color? Plus, the fork remains QR, while a lot of eBike MTB wheelsets (cheap and tough for commuting/touring/bikepacking as a chunky individual with a load) are boost these days; I'm wondering if they'll make a boost Ogre fork option, to go with the Gnot Boost rear 145 mm spacing.

data.text: I like e bikes even though I don't use one. But all the judging people pass on users of ebikes is silly. The best part of bike packing is being in the elements, adventuring, etc. For some the physical challenge is where it's at, and that's fine, but if it's not for some, who cares.

data.text: They are Jones H Bar Loop, they came as standard when I took delivery of my Bombtrack. First time I've used them always had flats or drops before now, but can't honestly see me going back to either ever again. So much 'cockpit' room, so many available hand positions, definitely a convert to these style of bars :D

data.text: I got my dream bikepacking bike already. Surly krampus. Such a fun bike for travelling! I do whant to do a wheel change tho. I have dat swiss 350 hubs and i think they reakt to slow. So whant to go hope in the back. And son dynamo in the front. And change the slx derailer and shifter to xt. Last summer I destroyed 2 pair of pedals in one trip (Kona wah wah and some other brand i forgot the name of ) got the Shimano saints and they hold up but are to small for my liking. So chromag daggas are coming in. Then it is perfect for me. Love this bike. So much fun. Climbs realy well. Eats up etheryting in its path and bombs downhills like theres no Tomorrow.

data.text: I have two that pretty much fit that category. My Ti Deluxe 29'er from Indy Fab with Ti Salsa post and Ti bars or my Singular Ti Gryphon... also with a Ti Salsa post. SRAM 1X12 on both, one with AXS and the other with 12 speed Microshift bar end shifter. Lots of other stuff too.... all old school geo.... not a fan of the new couch bike geo thing. Mind you, I've been mountain/gravel/CX/road riding for decades and still ride fully rigid bikes. Bags are made by me... SpoK Werks.
